meanings.definition: A clear, high-pitched sound made by forcing breath through a small hole between one's lips or teeth.
meanings.sent1: The referee blew the whistle to start the game.
meanings.sent2: I heard the whistle of the train as it approached the station.
meanings.sent3: The whistle of the kettle signaled that the water was boiling.
meanings.sent4: The whistle of the wind through the trees was soothing.
meanings.sent5: The loud whistle of the teapot made everyone jump.

meanings.definition: A device used to produce a loud, shrill sound by forcing air or steam through a small opening.
meanings.sent1: The lifeguard used a whistle to alert swimmers of danger.
meanings.sent2: The coach's whistle signaled the end of practice.
meanings.sent3: The whistle around the referee's neck was shiny and new.
meanings.sent4: The whistle of the kettle drowned out the conversation.
meanings.sent5: The loud whistle of the train echoed through the station.

meanings.definition: To make a high-pitched sound by forcing breath through one's lips or teeth.
meanings.sent1: I like to whistle while I work around the house.
meanings.sent2: The birds outside my window whistle every morning.
meanings.sent3: She tried to whistle a tune, but it came out all wrong.
meanings.sent4: The wind seemed to whistle through the cracks in the window.
meanings.sent5: The kettle began to whistle on the stove.

meanings.definition: To produce a loud, shrill sound by forcing air or steam through a small opening.
meanings.sent1: The kettle started to whistle as the water boiled.
meanings.sent2: The pressure cooker began to whistle, indicating it was ready.
meanings.sent3: The wind outside seemed to whistle through the trees.
meanings.sent4: The teapot started to whistle on the stove.
meanings.sent5: The referee will whistle if there is a foul during the game.
